text: Is end when used as sublist notation in Julia constant time? or does it calculate the length of the vector every time you call it?

text: If you use a normal vector, it calculates it every time. But it's a very fast operation, IIRC, it's a single movq instruction

elements.text: If you use a normal vector, it calculates it every time. But it's a very fast operation, IIRC, it's a single movq instruction

I wouldn't call a single `movq` "calculates" though, it's just retrieving the data from the heap

text:
I asked the question to understand which way is faster to run:
```function PercentageChange(input,output)
    N = length(input)
    output[1:1] .= missing
    output[2:N] .= @view(input[2:N]) ./ @view(input[1:N-1]) .- 1
    return output
end```
or
```function PercentageChange(input,output)
    output[1:1] .= missing
    output[2:end] .= @view(input[2:end]) ./ @view(input[1:end-1]) .- 1
    return output
end```

elements.text: I asked the question to understand which way is faster to run:

function PercentageChange(input,output)
    N = length(input)
    output[1:1] .= missing
    output[2:N] .= @view(input[2:N]) ./ @view(input[1:N-1]) .- 1
    return output
end
or

function PercentageChange(input,output)
    output[1:1] .= missing
    output[2:end] .= @view(input[2:end]) ./ @view(input[1:end-1]) .- 1
    return output
end

text: I guess this is a very small function, but (in a much larger function) if I use end many times and the length of the vector never changes, would it be worth just computing length once instead?

text: yes

elements.text: yes

text: moreover, only the first load of that length will be (comparatively to subsequent loads) "slow", because it's not cached yet. after that, the data already lives in L1 or L2 cache, which is much faster to access than regular RAM.

elements.text: moreover, only the first load of that length will be (comparatively to subsequent loads) "slow", because it's not cached yet. after that, the data already lives in L1 or L2 cache, which is much faster to access than regular RAM.

text: There's no need to worry or avoid `end`

end

text: Is there anywhere I can read why this doesn't scale?

text: It doesn't scale because StaticArrays uses tuples internally to place things on the stack. Once they get too large, the compiler has a hard time figuring out what you want

elements.text: It doesn't scale because StaticArrays uses tuples internally to place things on the stack. Once they get too large, the compiler has a hard time figuring out what you want

text: It doesn't scale in any language, because you stack is only so large.

elements.text: It doesn't scale in any language, because you stack is only so large.

text:
Is there any way to use end instead of computing the length here? Or is length also stored on the heap?
```function MovingAverage(period, input, output)
    N = length(input)
    output[1:(period-1)] .= missing
    sm = mean(@view input[1:period])
    output[period] = sm
    @inbounds @simd for i in (period+1):N
        sm += (input[i] - input[i-period]) / period
        output[i] = sm
    end
    return output
end```

elements.text: Is there any way to use end instead of computing the length here? Or is length also stored on the heap?

function MovingAverage(period, input, output)
    N = length(input)
    output[1:(period-1)] .= missing
    sm = mean(@view input[1:period])
    output[period] = sm
    @inbounds @simd for i in (period+1):N
        sm += (input[i] - input[i-period]) / period
        output[i] = sm
    end
    return output
end

text: `a[1:end]` is equivalent to `getindex(a, 1:lastindex(a))`

elements.text: a[1:end]
is equivalent to
getindex(a, 1:lastindex(a))

text: yes

elements.text: yes

text:
```julia> Meta.@lower a[1:end]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.lastindex(a)
│   %2 = 1:%1
│   %3 = Base.getindex(a, %2)
└──      return %3
))))```

elements.text:
julia> Meta.@lower a[1:end]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.lastindex(a)
│   %2 = 1:%1
│   %3 = Base.getindex(a, %2)
└──      return %3
))))
